content:
Hi, 
I suggest to add a test with number = 1000000001332 and D=3
My code goes through all the tests and validators though it would output 1332 in that case.
Good puzzle anyway.
Added "Remove 1 digit validator" and "Remove 2 digits" testcase.
Made some minor wording and layout changes to the statement. Added "write answer" to stub generator.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a very good puzzle. It would have been better if the maximum number of digits to be removed were given as input.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est réellement un puzzle facile.
Nice puzzle ^^ .Very clear

Nice puzzle, but I would phrase if a bit more clearly, like:
Given a number N, output the highest number M that satisfices the following rules:
* M is achieved by removing between 0 and 2 digits from N;
* M is divisible by D.
I would also delete rule 3 and build the tests such that a solution always exists. Otherwise a cheater may solve this as "print(0)" and get some score.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice easy puzzle.

I don't think you should include the last paragraph in the statement. Additionally this is an easy problem in my opinion.

I'd also like to know, why did you make it so it stops after removing 2 digits? This seems arbitrary and adds complexity to what would have been a pretty straight forward problem. You would just specify "the output number can be made by removing any number of digits from the original number, while not modifying the order of the digits." Can you explain why you set the limit? Thanks.
It's confusing when you call 'a number' (highlighted input) and 'the number' (output ). To differentiate them I suggest using something like 'input number' and 'output number' or call input as 'A'.

I find the instructions, and in particular the sentence, "You should remove at most two digits" to be slightly ambiguous.  I initially took it to mean that the largest number possible is always within two digits of the given number.  (Perhaps conditional upon on its existence; i.e., if it does exist, then it can be found by removing at most two digits.)  Perhaps the instructions could merge that sentence with the previous one.  Personally, I would give an enumeration of the desired properties that the solution should have.  Something like: "given a number, and a target divisor, D, create the largest number possible that:

1. is divisible by D
2. uses only digits from the given number
3. uses each digit of the original number at most once
4. uses the digits in the same order in which they appear in the given number
5. leaves out at most two digits of the given number"

Even that still leaves some ambiguity.  For example, given an original number 555567, are we allowed to use more than one 5 in our solution?

Is this better?

Given an input number, output the largest number possible that follows these rules:
1. The output number must be divisible by D
2. The output number must be created by removing between 0 and 2 digits from the input number (you cannot change the order of the digits)
3. If it is not possible to make a number following the above rules, your number is 0

For example:
314159
3

Should output
31419

Your program should first check if 314159 is divisible by 3. Since it is not, your program should try different combinations of removing a single digit; 31415, 31419, 31459, 31159, 34159, 14159. The second possibility (of removing a single digit) tested fits the rules, so that is your number. If it didn't, you would continue by removing two digits at a time; 3141, 3145, 3115, 3415, 1415, 3149, 3149, 3119, 3419, 1419... and so on.
Thanks for the feedback :)

Thanks for the feedback :)

I based this on one of the programming challenges I completed in Google's foo.bar (it was my first challenge). The challenge was essentially the same as this except all numbers had to be divisible by three and there was no limit to how many digits you can remove, but you only ever had to remove at most two.
Thanks :)

I feel like that's just a minor rewording and it wouldn't really impact the way someone understands the problem much if at all. Also print(0) shouldn't work because only one of the tests (and its validator) actually result in 0... If that's not what you meant or I misunderstood please explain to me. Thanks for your feedback :)
Thanks :)
Thanks :)
Thanks :)

Just in case it isn't clear:  If the goal were (as in the Google problem you describe) to find a number divisible by 3, specifically, then the limit of 2 isn't needed.  One would never need to remove more than two digits anyway.  If there were a solution that removed 3 or more digits, then some subset of the digits to be removed would sum to 3, modulo 3, and if one were to not remove those, one would get a bigger number that satisfies the other requirements.  (Because the base of 10 is equivalent to 1, mod 3, decimal numbers are therefore equivalent (mod 3) to the sums of their digits.)

As it stands, this is a somewhat different problem.  It's perhaps a bit easier, because everything is spelled out for the programmer.
Yeah, that looks good to me!
Thanks for the feedback :)
This last is really better. Made it. It is a easy one. Ok to me in your last version.
